recommendations.title: evidence-based risk and legal review
recommendations.text:
While India has taken a measured approach to AI governance, so far, the increasing integration of AI 
across sectors brings a growing range of complex risks, spanning technical failures, ethical concerns, 
societal harms, legal ambiguities, economic disruptions, environmental costs and national security 
threats. Without a standardized framework to identify, classify and assess these risks, governance 
efforts may become fragmented and inconsistent. 
During consultations, stakeholders highlighted that a lack of research on AI risks and the absence of 
a common taxonomy on harms may result in fragmented regulation, overlaps and gaps in oversight, 
and inconsistent treatment of similar risks. To address this, it is recommended that India conduct a 
comprehensive AI risk-mapping exercise and develop a shared risk/harm taxonomy. Further, a gap 
analysis of existing legal frameworks may also be taken up, as suggested in the short-term action 
plan of the AI Governance Guidelines.417 These steps will clarify the scope and severity of AI-related 
risks, and help ensure more consistent, proportionate and adaptable regulatory responses across 
sectors.
RATIONALE
India’s AI Safety Institute may undertake a comprehensive AI risk-mapping and 
taxonomy development exercise
The AI Safety Institute (AISI), in consultation with both the AI governance group and the 
technology and policy expert committee proposed under the AI Governance Guidelines, may 
initiate a coordinated, cross-sectoral study to map and assess emerging and existing AI-related 
risks. This exercise should be undertaken in collaboration with academic institutions, industry 
stakeholders, civil society, and policy think tanks. A key input into this risk mapping process

recommendations.title: AI developers and deployers
recommendations.text:
During consultations, stakeholders highlighted that translating high-level ethical AI principles 
such as fairness, accountability, transparency and safety into actionable AI practices remains a key 
barrier to ethical and effective deployment of AI. Without practical tools or guidance, developers 
and deployers often struggle to integrate these principles into design and implementation life cycles.
Recognizing these challenges, India has already begun supporting the development of practical, 
techno-legal solutions through initiatives under the IndiaAI Mission. Under the Safe & Trusted 
AI pillar, the government has issued two expressions of interest (EOIs) to develop tools, frameworks 
and self-assessment mechanisms tailored to India’s institutional and developmental context. 
The establishment of the IndiaAI Safety Institute further advances this objective, serving as the 
national anchor institution for guiding responsible AI development and helping convert ethical 
principles into operational practices across sectors. Building on these initiatives, India may continue 
to expand and institutionalize such tools to ensure that practical, implementable mechanisms for 
ethical AI become widely accessible across the ecosystem.
RATIONALE
The AI Safety Institute, in collaboration with private entities, may establish 
a voluntary repository of ethical AI practices 
The AI Safety Institute (AISI), under the IndiaAI Mission, may establish a dynamic, publicly 
accessible repository of existing practices for operationalizing and contextualizing ethical 
principles according to India’s needs. In doing so, the AISI may be empowered to conduct 
research, analysis and testing, collaborate with international bodies, support industry 
compliance and contribute to the development of standards. This platform can enable 
governments, AI developers/companies and researchers to voluntarily contribute their existing

CHAPTER 1 
Diagnosis of the national AI landscape
AI governance in India: an overview of legal structure, policies and institutions
India has a quasi-federal structure. Under India’s Constitution, legislative powers are distributed 
between the centre and the states through three lists: the Union List, the State List, and the Concurrent 
List. Each branch plays an important role in shaping the trajectory of AI in India.
The Union List includes subjects on which only the Union Legislature may make laws, such as telegraphs, 
telephones, wireless, and broadcasting. The State List includes matters where states exercise exclusive 
authority, such as police, public health, law and order, and education. The Concurrent List allows both 
the centre and the states to legislate on subjects such as criminal law and insolvency, with central law 
prevailing in case of conflict. This federal design ensures that policy-making reflects India’s diversity: 
states have both the power and the obligation to adapt national frameworks to local conditions, 
making governance inherently contextual and negotiated. 
Parliament 
The Indian Parliament remains central to the lawmaking process, with the power to debate and pass 
bills introduced by the executive. Additionally, members of parliament regularly exercise oversight 
by raising questions or interventions related to AI policies, ethics and safety, investments, global 
cooperation, and regulatory approaches, and by introducing private member bills.3 Parliamentary 
committees play a key role in examining government action – particularly the Standing Committee 
on Communications and Information Technology,4 which has selected, among other subjects, the 
‘Impact of emergence of Artificial Intelligence and related issues’ for examination.
The executive
The President of India is the constitutional head of the executive at the union level. A Council of

recommendations.title: Advance public trust in AI through governance, procurement
recommendations.text:
While the benefits of AI are increasingly visible across sectors in India, concerns around its risks and 
potential harms have also led to trust issues, especially in a context of unequal digital literacy. While 
data indicated optimism around the usage of AI, stakeholder consultations highlighted that public 
trust may be weakened by the lack of better understanding of how AI systems work, how personal 
data is used, and what safeguards exist for users. This uncertainty often leads to confusion, fear 
and resistance. As a major adopter of, and standard setter for AI, the Indian Government is uniquely 
positioned to set baseline norms for responsible AI use. By embedding transparency features in its 
own AI use and investing in public awareness, it can build trust, set clear standards and show what 
responsible deployment looks like. This will not only boost public confidence but also create a culture 
of accountability and user-first design across the AI ecosystem.

recommendations.title: embedding ethics and supporting inclusive transitions
recommendations.text:
The RAM consultations highlighted that while India is making strong strides in AI skilling, key 
challenges persist. Skills gaps, job displacement risks and a shortage of qualified AI educators remain 
key concerns. Many mid-career professionals lack clear upskilling pathways, while informal workers 
and those outside metro cities face limited access to quality AI education. In addition, the public 
sector needs to strengthen its ability to procure, govern and deploy AI responsibly, considering the 
growing emphasis on AI governance and AI-powered public service delivery. 
There is also a need to shift focus from AI fluency to AI competence, to improve employability and 
align with market expectations. Ethics and safety in AI must be integral parts of these programmes 
to ensure an AI workforce that is both competent and ethically aware. To prepare for this shift, India 
should adopt a three-pronged approach: evaluate ongoing efforts; build AI competence and ethical 
AI knowledge across sectors, including the public sector; and anticipate labour market transitions 
driven by automation.
RATIONALE
The Ministry of Skill Development and Entrepreneurship may evaluate the National 
Skilling Framework and accelerate implementation of pending recommendations
The Ministry of Skill Development and Entrepreneurship (Skill Development Ministry) may 
conduct a comprehensive evaluation and review of the implementation of the National 
Programme on AI Skilling Framework (NPAI-SF’s) recommendations and identify bottlenecks, 
especially in the context of AI skilling schemes across government and industry. The evaluation 
could focus on the ability of programmes and initiatives to build real competence, their 
effectiveness for translation into industry-required jobs, and their emphasis on integrating ethical 
aspects of AI with technical skilling. In addition, a review of the Capacity Building Commission’s

recommendations.title: into AI infrastructure planning and deployment
recommendations.text:
As India scales up AI adoption, there is a critical need to address environmental sustainability. 
The rising environmental footprint of large-scale AI systems, including data centres and compute 
clusters, requires that sustainability be embedded into infrastructure planning from the outset. This 
includes integrating clean energy solutions, encouraging the use of energy-efficient AI models and 
developing regulatory mechanisms to assess environmental impact.
To ensure long-term equity and resilience, infrastructure expansion must be coupled with targeted 
research and development (R&D) support and innovation funding beyond metro hubs, enabling 
the emergence of grassroots innovation ecosystems. Strengthening local compute capacity, 
fostering applied AI research and enabling sustainable design practices are essential to building an 
AI ecosystem that is not only nationally scalable but also environmentally and socially responsible.
RATIONALE
ROADMAP
7.1
The Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change and the IndiaAI Mission 
may devise a comprehensive environmental impact assessment for large-scale AI 
infrastructure.
India’s existing environmental impact assessment (EIA) framework may be expanded to cover 
large-scale AI infrastructure such as data centres, compute clusters and AI test beds, which are 
currently not subject to sector-specific environmental scrutiny. Given the unique sustainability 
challenges posed by AI systems, including high energy demands and the environmental impact 
of digital infrastructure, it would be beneficial to develop tailored evaluation criteria within the 
existing EIA process. Further, such an EIA can highlight areas of particular ecological sensitivity 
and help identify optimal locations for AI infrastructure like data centres. The Environment

recommendations.title: AI workforce and research and development ecosystem
recommendations.text:
India’s AI ecosystem must be inclusive by design. Currently, the representation of women, rural 
populations and marginalized communities remains limited across AI research, education and the 
workforce. This under-representation risks embedding bias not only in datasets and algorithms, but 
in the direction of innovation itself. Promoting diversity is a matter of equity along with producing 
more representative and responsible AI outcomes.
The Skill Development Ministry, the IT Ministry and leading academic institutions may co-develop 
targeted interventions to ensure the inclusion of under-represented groups in AI careers and research. 
These efforts must go beyond high-level policy commitments and be embedded into public skilling, 
funding and research pipelines.

Translating core learning resources, tutorials and assessments into major Indian languages 
and delivering them through local training centres will help expand access to AI education 
and ensure that non-English-speaking learners are fully included in the opportunities of an

legal_regulatory.title: Legal and Regulatory
findings: Legal and regulatory dimension The legal and regulatory dimension of the RAM evaluates India’s readiness to govern AI.
This chapter maps India’s efforts to build AI governance frameworks while maintaining regulatory agility and ensuring AI technologies are safe, accountable and aligned with constitutional values.

This includes examining AI policy development, data protection and privacy laws; procurement rules; transparency mechanisms like the Right to Information (RTI); and human rights frameworks such as freedom of expression and due process.
It also tracks the maturity of institutional safeguards, including grievance redress systems and accountability mechanisms across the AI value chain.

Concurrently, sectoral regulators are examining AI governance within their respective domains, with financial, telecommunications and health regulators developing sector-specific standards and requirements tailored to address domain- specific risks and create accountability mechanisms.

Evolution of AI regulation and policy A key starting point for India’s deliberations on AI governance can be traced to 2017, with the constitution of a task force on artificial intelligence by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry (Commerce Ministry).
The resulting report, published in 2018, explicitly acknowledged the importance of ethical and safe AI, calling for the development of ethical frameworks to guide responsible AI deployment in India.

It also recommended the creation of a National AI Mission – an inter-ministerial nodal agency to coordinate AI-related activities in India.33 In ensuing years, several government-constituted multistakeholder expert committees have deliberated on a potential AI governance framework for India; the out
strengths: The task force was established to recommend a policy and legal framework for the deployment of AI technologies and to provide guidance for government, industry and research institutions.
This programme culminated in the IndiaAI Mission, launched in 2024.

findings: Social and cultural dimension The social and cultural dimension of the RAM outlines how inclusion, diversity, public awareness and environmental considerations shape the development and deployment of AI systems.
In the Indian context, these priorities are closely linked to the government’s AI for All vision, which aims to ensure that the benefits of AI reach all segments of society.
This chapter also explores gender representation in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and the broader AI workforce.
Public engagement with digital platforms and trust in AI systems, including perceptions of fairness and data use, are discussed as indicators of public acceptance.
It also reviews the integration of AI into healthcare and disability services, and the impact of AI tools on children.

Finally, this dimension reviews initiatives supporting linguistic and cultural diversity through AI, as well as national- and state-level approaches to environmental sustainability in AI infrastructure.
